Name: *Safety Checklist Completion*
Description: The Test Solution shall comply with the Test Equipment Safety Checklist  074-8434-282.

Paragraphs: The Test Solution shall comply with the Test Equipment Safety Checklist  074-8434-282.
The Test Solution shall comply with the Test Equipment Safety Checklist  074-8434-282.
[text4] Completion of the Test Equipment safety checklist is a requirement for test equipment release per HRC-OPS-I-752.

[validation_evidence$193] Completion of the Test Equipment safety checklist is a requirement for test equipment release per HRC-OPS-I-752. The requirement has been evaluated per Appendix B Requirements Validation Checklist in the Requirements Management Plan 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Test Data Archiving
Description:
The Test System shall generate and store test data outputs in TDMS.

 

NOTE: For specific projects, the specific data repository tool (TDMS/MES/etc.) required by the project should be specified here.

If the test station is off the network, capture portable storage or firewall requirements.

Paragraphs: The Test System shall generate and store test data outputs in TDMS.
NOTE: For specific projects, the specific data repository tool (TDMS/MES/etc.) required by the project should be specified here.
If the test station is off the network, capture portable storage or firewall requirements.
The Test System shall generate and store test data outputs in TDMS.
NOTE: For specific projects, the specific data repository tool (TDMS/MES/etc.) required by the project should be specified here.
If the test station is off the network, capture portable storage or firewall requirements.
[text3] This often comes from the MEE on the program. Identify whether TDMS or another database needs to receive test logs.
[validation_evidence$193] The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Connector/Cable Mating Protection
Description: The Test System Hardware shall be designed so that cables cannot be reversed or plugged into the wrong connector.

Paragraphs: The Test System Hardware shall be designed so that cables cannot be reversed or plugged into the wrong connector.
The Test System Hardware shall be designed so that cables cannot be reversed or plugged into the wrong connector.

[text3] Reversed cables can lead to damage to the UUT when power is applied or bent pins when the cables are mated. It is important to prevent this from occurring as this can lead to significant rework and repair being required on the production UUT in question. In some rare cases, the UUT may be scrapped due to the expected repair cost. However, in some cases where limited connector mates are available, this may not be practical. Therefore, it is critical to work with the design engineering team early on in this process for mates to the UUT.

[validation_evidence$193] See Rationale and also if not applicable, identify the reason such as the connector mates are not reversible and no alternative exists. In such cases, the requirement may be updated to indicate that special labels or other visual indicators are to be used to protect the UUT From damage. The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Keyed Connectors/Cables
Description: All connectors and cables with keying shall be correctly keyed to their mating point.

Paragraphs: All connectors and cables with keying shall be correctly keyed to their mating point.
All connectors and cables with keying shall be correctly keyed to their mating point.

[text3] Often times keying is wrong on connectors. Built fixtures and drawings need to be inspected and connection must be demonstrated to ensure that the keying is properly documented and implemented in the test equipment.
[validation_evidence$193] The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Operator Input Test Sequence Grouping
Description: All tests requiring operator input shall be grouped at the beginning or end of the test sequence, unless otherwise specified by the critical test order in the ATP.

Paragraphs: All tests requiring operator input shall be grouped at the beginning or end of the test sequence, unless otherwise specified by the critical test order in the ATP.
All tests requiring operator input shall be grouped at the beginning or end of the test sequence, unless otherwise specified by the critical test order in the ATP.
[text3] This is a stakeholder requirement from MEEs in order to be able to optimize the workflow for a test technician who might be running tests on multiple test stations at the same time.
[validation_evidence$193] The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Test Prompt Clarity
Description:
Test Prompts shall be consistent, clear, and auditable throughout.

 

NOTE:

TE will make prompts clear as possible. TE will review with MEE and techs prior to wording finalization.

These conversations should take place during ATM creation.

Paragraphs: Test Prompts shall be consistent, clear, and auditable throughout.
TE will make prompts clear as possible. TE will review with MEE and techs prior to wording finalization.
These conversations should take place during ATM creation.
Test Prompts shall be consistent, clear, and auditable throughout.
TE will make prompts clear as possible. TE will review with MEE and techs prior to wording finalization.
These conversations should take place during ATM creation.

[text3] The prompts need to be clear enough that any reasonable person can complete the instructions. In the past, there have existed test prompts that might reference unreleased or nonexistent documents. If a tool is required to perform an action, reference the tool. If a signal needs to be probed, where is it? If a cable needs to be plugged in, which cable, plugged into what and when. etc...
[validation_evidence$193] The source of this is the MEE. The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Identification Markings
Description:
All Final/Top level test equipment shall have the corresponding part number, revision, and serial number clearly marked on the equipment per HRC-OPS-P-071.

 

NOTE: See HRC-ENG-I-001, Product Definition Preparation and Release, for marking and product definition instructions.

Name: Test Data Sheet Contents
Description:
The Test System Software shall produce a Test Data Sheet that contains the following information:

a. Product serial number at the sellable level of assembly.

b. Product revision level/status.

c. Product part number.

d. Test equipment software part number(s).

e. ATP revision level/status.

f. Calendar date test performed.

g. Quantitative values measured for each test step.

h. Pass/Fail criterial for each test step.

Paragraphs: The Test System Software shall produce a Test Data Sheet that contains the following information:
a. Product serial number at the sellable level of assembly.
d. Test equipment software part number(s).
g. Quantitative values measured for each test step.
h. Pass/Fail criterial for each test step.
The Test System Software shall produce a Test Data Sheet that contains the following information:
a. Product serial number at the sellable level of assembly.
d. Test equipment software part number(s).
g. Quantitative values measured for each test step.
h. Pass/Fail criterial for each test step.

Name: Tier 1 Boundary Scan Coverage
Description:
The Test System shall be capable of performing Tier 1 Boundary Scan coverage of the UUT.

 

NOTE:

  • The descriptions for the various tiers are as described below and specific features may be articulated as decomposed requirements for different projects.

    • Tier 1:  Boundary Scan tests and programming accessible on the UUT only.  Typically requires simple connection of power and the JTAG bus to the UUT.  Actions that can be generated from the Bscan tool menu for Tier 1 level actions are Bscan chain check, interconnect screens between scannable devices on the chain, screens for memory devices accessible from a scannable device, and programming/configuration of memory devices accessible from a scannable device.

    • Tier 2:  External fixtured BScan I/O to expand coverage through edge connectors

    • Tier 3:  Everything else.  If you have to do scripting, cluster testing, non-bscan type sublevel elements are all Tier 3

Paragraphs: The Test System shall be capable of performing Tier 1 Boundary Scan coverage of the UUT.

Tier 1:  Boundary Scan tests and programming accessible on the UUT only.  Typically requires simple connection of power and the JTAG bus to the UUT.  Actions that can be generated from the Bscan tool menu for Tier 1 level actions are Bscan chain check, interconnect screens between scannable devices on the chain, screens for memory devices accessible from a scannable device, and programming/configuration of memory devices accessible from a scannable device.
Tier 2:  External fixtured BScan I/O to expand coverage through edge connectors
Tier 3:  Everything else.  If you have to do scripting, cluster testing, non-bscan type sublevel elements are all Tier 3
The Test System shall be capable of performing Tier 1 Boundary Scan coverage of the UUT.

Tier 1:  Boundary Scan tests and programming accessible on the UUT only.  Typically requires simple connection of power and the JTAG bus to the UUT.  Actions that can be generated from the Bscan tool menu for Tier 1 level actions are Bscan chain check, interconnect screens between scannable devices on the chain, screens for memory devices accessible from a scannable device, and programming/configuration of memory devices accessible from a scannable device.
Tier 2:  External fixtured BScan I/O to expand coverage through edge connectors
Tier 3:  Everything else.  If you have to do scripting, cluster testing, non-bscan type sublevel elements are all Tier 3

[validation_evidence$193] This requirement would be outlined at bid time and so would have traceability to the bid slide deck. The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Boundary Scan Tool Software
Description:
The Boundary Scan Test System shall use XJTAG boundary scan software.

 

NOTE:

  • The three primary boundary scan tools used at Collins are XJTAG XJRunner, Asset Intertech ScanWorks, and JTAG Technologies Provision/AEX Manager.

Paragraphs: The Boundary Scan Test System shall use XJTAG boundary scan software.
The Boundary Scan Test System shall use XJTAG boundary scan software.

[validation_evidence$193] The use of which boundary scan vendor software is typically determined at the bid phase and can be referenced there. In some cases, the decision may be made in the design plan to switch to a different tool in which case, the validation method should be linked to the design plan and potentially marked as engineering judgement. The requirement passes all validation criteria outlined in Appendix B of the RMP 946-3FG8-001 Rev A.

Name: Display Processor Power Requirements
Description:
The Bscan test system shall provide the following voltages at the maximum UUT currents to the UUT pins specified in the table below.

 

Power-up Order

The +15V rail must be >+13V before the +3.3V and +1.8V rails come up.


The +3.3V rail and +1.8V rails must ramp from 0V to operational level in no more than 12 ms.

 

The +3.3V and +1.8V rail startup ramp must occur within 8 ms of each other.

 

It is advisable that the full power-up sequence take no longer than 20ms.

 

Additionally: The +3.3 and +1.8V rails must ramp from operational level to 0V within 20 ms of each other on power-down.

+3.3V

+3.3V +/- 0.08V

< 2 Amps

N/A

< 3 Amps

P1-1, 9, 15, 22, 28, 35, 41, 82, 90, 96, 103, 109, 116, and 122

Name: 828-1A60-001 File Programming and Verification
Description:
The 828-1A60-001 Boundary Scan Application shall program and verify the files listed in the following table with respective FILE NAME, FILE ADDRESS RANGE, DEVICE START ADDRESS, FILL DATA, and FILE CRC.

 

 

NOTE: 

  • The programming parameters table comes from the CCA Drawing 828-1A60-001 Rev N.
  • Item 140 is 072-2874-002
  • Item 141 is 9833-0941-003
  • Verification of this requirement includes both inspection of the test software and a test run of the software.
    • Inspection verification involves inspecting the following elements in the test application software at a minimum: FILE NAME, FILE ADDRESS RANGE, DEVICE START ADDRESS, FILL DATA, FILE CRC, and the Device the respective file is programmed to.
    • Test verification involves the running of the programming and verify actions to ensure that both actions pass.
  • A bit by bit verification of the data which will be executed during the verification phase of this requirement to supersede verifying the Device Checksum after each load.
  • A verification of the data load will be executed using the vendor tool at the verification phase of this requirement to supersede verifying the Device Checksum after each load

Paragraphs: The 828-1A60-001 Boundary Scan Application shall program and verify the files listed in the following table with respective FILE NAME, FILE ADDRESS RANGE, DEVICE START ADDRESS, FILL DATA, and FILE CRC.

    • A bit by bit verification of the data which will be executed during the verification phase of this requirement to supersede verifying the Device Checksum after each load.

    • Inspection verification involves inspecting the following elements in the test application software at a minimum: FILE NAME, FILE ADDRESS RANGE, DEVICE START ADDRESS, FILL DATA, FILE CRC, and the Device the respective file is programmed to.
    • Test verification involves the running of the programming and verify actions to ensure that both actions pass.
    • A bit by bit verification of the data which will be executed during the verification phase of this requirement to supersede verifying the Device Checksum after each load.
    • A verification of the data load will be executed using the vendor tool at the verification phase of this requirement to supersede verifying the Device Checksum after each load

Paragraphs: The 2600-0860-002 Boundary Scan Application shall program and verify the files listed in the following table with respective FILE NAME, FILE ADDRESS RANGE, DEVICE START ADDRESS, FILL DATA, and FILE CRC.

Name: IO CCA JTAG Interface
Description:
The test hardware shall interface with the UUT's P1 connector, supplying power to the UUTs

The test hardware shall interface with either the 2600-0860-002 or 2600-0870-002 P2 and P3 Test and JTAG Signals connectors, respectively.

The test hardware shall interface with the 828-1A60-001 P6 and P2 connectors, provide access for Test and JTAG Signals, respectively.

 

 

CCA Signal Name Test Connector (P2) JTAG Connector (P3)
2600-0860-002 TCK Pin 4 Pin 6
TDO Pin 6 Pin 3
TDI Pin 8 Pin 2
2600-0870-002 TMS Pin 10 Pin 4
VREF (+3.3V) Pin 9 Pin 1
GND Pins 1, 3, 48, 50 Pin 5
       
  Signal Name Test Connector (P6) JTAG Connector (P2)
828-1A60-001 TCK Pin 4 Pin 6
TDO Pin 6 Pin 8
TDI Pin 8 Pin 10
TMS Pin 10 Pin 4
VREF (+3.3V) Pin 9 Pin 2
GND Pins 1, 3, 28, 48, 50 Pins 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13

*Note 2600 series does not have a ground on P2-28

Paragraphs: The test hardware shall interface with the UUT's P1 connector, supplying power to the UUTs
The test hardware shall interface with either the 2600-0860-002 or 2600-0870-002 P2 and P3 Test and JTAG Signals connectors, respectively.
The test hardware shall interface with the 828-1A60-001 P6 and P2 connectors, provide access for Test and JTAG Signals, respectively.
*Note 2600 series does not have a ground on P2-28

Name: Display Processor JTAG Interface
Description:
The IO CCA Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT P5/P4 connectors shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.

 

Signal UUT P4 Pin
+3.3V 1
Ground 7, 8
BST_TDI 3
BST_TMS 5
BST_TDO 2
BST_TRST_L 4
BST_TCK 6
 
Signal UUT P5 Pin
+3.3V 2
Ground 1, 13
MB_FPGA_TDI 3
MB_FPGA_TMS 5
MB_FPGA_TCK 7
MB_FPGA_TRST 11
MB_FPGA_TDO 9
PLD_TDI 4
PLD_TMS 6
PLD_TCK 8
PLD_TDO 10
PFM_DIS_L (no connection) 12
OSC_DIS_L (no connection) 14

Paragraphs: The IO CCA Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT P5/P4 connectors shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.

Name: Sensor Suite Controller JTAG Interface
Description:
The IO CCA Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT P1 connector shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.

 
 
Signal UUT P1 Pin
+3V3_VDC 2
FPGA_TMS 4
FPGA_TCK 6
FPGA_TDO 8
FPGA_TDI 10
DIGITAL_GND 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13

Paragraphs: The IO CCA Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT P1 connector shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.

Name: LCD Controller JTAG Interface
Description:
The LCD Controller Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT J13 connector shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.

 
Signal UUT J13 Pin
+3.3VDC 2
JTAG_TMS 4
JTAG_TCK 6
JTAG_TDO 8
JTAG_TDI 10
JTAG_CONNECTED_L 11
DIGITAL_GND 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 13

Paragraphs: The LCD Controller Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT J13 connector shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.

Name: HCP Primary JTAG Interface
Description:
The HCP Primary Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT P3 connector shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.

 
Signal UUT P3 Pin
+3.3VDC 6
JTAG_TCK 1
JTAG_TDO 3
JTAG_TMS 5
JTAG_TRSTB 8
JTAG_TDI 9
DIGITAL_GND 2, 10

Paragraphs: The HCP Primary Test Hardware shall connect the following pins on the UUT P3 connector shown below to the respective signal pins on the JTAG Pod.
